speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 14-613, Green v. Brennan. Mr. Wolfman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What does the statute say? Can we look at the statute? What's it -- what does the statute say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The matter alleged to be discriminatory. And is the resignation of -- of the employee a matter alleged to be discriminatory?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The employee discriminated against himself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But for a constructive discharge claim to succeed you have to point to a discriminatory or an unlawful act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And so we have to find this anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course. That's -- that rule is adopted for statutes that do not have a conciliation provision. What use is the conciliation provision once the employee has quit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's fine, but the employer can make it up, you know. It's -- they try to bring the employer and the employee together.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But he's quit. He's gone. He's no longer an employee. What conciliation can there be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I somehow feel you've given up too much. You can charge a discriminatory termination, correct? And that's the employer making a decision that he is going to fire you for reasons that are not legitimate; they're discriminatory. Isn't a constructive discharge that the moment that the environment has gotten so hostile that you feel overwhelmed and have to leave, isn't that the discriminatory act as well?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So that that discharge itself is discriminatory because it -- the employer has proceeded in a pattern that has led you to that decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's what I'm saying. I don't think -- I think it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You keep talking about it as two separate elements. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the precipitating --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They're -- they're not always the same at the same point. The employer could have been discriminating against this employee for years, and -- and there's no additional discrimination for an entire year. But the employee has finally gotten fed up with it, and after a year, during which the employer has done nothing else discriminatory, he decides I'm going to quit. Now he'd still have a claim for, you know, discriminatory provoking of -- of the quitting, but the -- but the time period for the discrimination and the time period for the quitting are a year apart.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It is an act of the employer, and quitting is not an act of the employer. The act of the employer -- the unlawful act of the employer is coercing the quitting. So you have to find an act on his part that coerces the quitting. That's quite different from the employer discharging the person --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- for discriminatory --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For purpose of remedy, yes, it is. It's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Wolfman --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If -- you might be pulled in two different directions here but you don't have to accept what Justice Sotomayor is saying to win this case; isn't that right? In other words, one could say, yes, if you had discriminatory acts language, that might point to the last predicate discriminatory act as opposed to the resignation, it might or it might not, but here that language doesn't exist. Here the language is discriminatory matter. That refers to the entire claim. And when you refer to the entire claim, it's clear that the resignation is part and parcel of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And it at least creates ambiguity, such that the default rule would operate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So you don't have not to go to that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why doesn't that mean that it's within the employee's ability to stretch out the time that he has? Plus there could have been all this discrimination and the employee stays on the job, and then sometime down the road decides to quit.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, not -- not years but maybe several months. I mean, you know, yes, you can't take it anymore, but maybe you also need a paycheck or -- or, you know, you're going to be eligible for the bonus in six weeks, you may as well at least wait until then.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: May I follow up on Alderson Reporting Company Justice Kagan's question? You were discussing the possibility of deciding this case based on the particular language of the regulation that applies here, but your question presented is phrased much more broadly. You say under Federal employment discrimination law, so I took that to mean that the rule that you're advocating would be the same for public and private sector employment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But there is --  this matter alleged to be discriminatory applies only to Federal employment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Isn't it true that outside of the area of constructive discharge --  and maybe constructive discharge is different, and I think that's really the thrust of your argument. But outside of that situation there must be an act of intentional discrimination within the limitations period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Yeah, but you're arguing that there's --  because there's this imputation, it's different for constructive discharge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But my --  my question is outside of that context, under Evans and Ricks and Morgan and Ledbetter, there must be an act of intentional discrimination within the limitations period.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but I think the government suggests that this is exactly a case where it's not so easy to figure out when the constructive termination was.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: When the resignation occurred.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that doesn't mean it was easy or -- or hard.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you know that the case -- you know, someone says this is ridiculous, I can't take it anymore, I will resign in three months. I mean, what is the date of constructive termination then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No. He says -- I -- I interpreted the Chief Justice's question, maybe wrongly, suppose he says in his own mind I can't take it anymore, Alderson Reporting Company three months from now I'm going to resign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When he resigns?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When he resigns?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, no. The date that he says it to himself or the date that he does resign?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no. It's -- it's, you know, I think it's fairly common for people to set a resignation date at some point in the future. You know, a schoolteacher will say as soon as this school year is over, I'm out of here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then no --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's no cause of action yet.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You mean -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's no cause --  you've been --  you've been arguing to us you can't have the statute running until there's a cause of action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's still getting paid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He hasn't resigned. He's given notice of his intention to resign three months from now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: --  I'm just adopting the rule of what he says. If he says I resign, he's resigned. If he says I will resign in three months, he doesn't resign until three months.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Gannon.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why don't you change --  why don't you just amend the regulation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: We're interpreting the language --  it's not even a statute. It's a regulation. It's your regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why don't you just amend it to make it clear? You think this is a sensible rule, it is a very clear rule. And it's probably a sensible rule when you've got a 45-day period. Why don't you just change the regulation? Why --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: --  this elaborate litigation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But Ricks --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Ricks alleged only discrimination, not discriminatory -- not constructive discharge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's why I have a problem with Ricks.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, I don't think Alderson Reporting Company Ricks reads directly on what you're saying. You --  you want to have an extension.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But again, as Justice Scalia points out, there's a difference between the employee taking the action and the --  and the employer taking the action --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: --  and that distinguishes Ricks.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me you're -- you're loading the dice when --  when you say it requires both a decision to resign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It --  it requires a resignation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, that's --  that's the problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, we weren't discussing this very issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He doesn't even have to tell the employer why he's resigning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, all the employer knows is you're --  you're leaving at the end of this term of --  of school.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or you're leaving in three months. That's all the employer knows. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He doesn't even have to specify in his notice of quitting that he is quitting because of discriminatory action. He doesn't even have to specify that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think whether he has to say that or not has a lot to do with -- with when the effective date ought to be, it seems to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But he doesn't have to say that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He doesn't have to say I can't take this anymore --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He just has to quit or say I'm quitting at the end of this term of school, and then later say, oh, the reason I quit was it was I just couldn't take it anymore.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Within days after -- after when?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: After his giving the notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, I would --  I would take the term constructive discharge to refer not to the notice of quitting, but rather to the acts of the employer that forced the quitting. Even though the person hasn't been discharged, you have constructively discharged him because you've made his life miserable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that --  that works the same way with eviction and other cases where you have constructive, that the person has to act --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What do you mean, constructively? I don't understand. Constructive of -- can't you bring a claim of constructive eviction while you're still occupying the premises?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But in fact you don't have to get out. I think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You can bring -- you can bring a claim against your landlord for constructive eviction while you're still occupying the premises.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do the predicate acts have to be independently actionable or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you explain the difference between your position and the Petitioner's? Why do you date the constructive discharge from, what is it, December 16th?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But he was given a choice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He was given a choice of the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then read on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, suppose he showed up in --  in Wyoming? What would you have done?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Wouldn't you have allowed him to take that job at the lower pay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No. No. You said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It's not a breach.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The agreement says if he hasn't taken all the steps, if it does not occur, Mr. Green will report for duty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In Wyoming.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why not have the second sentence there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why have the second sentence there at all? Why are you giving him an option if he's -- if he hasn't retired?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: There was not reached by the court below, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Frankly, I'm a little less moved by that because, from my personal experience, those stale claims generally don't make it past a motion to dismiss.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Very few of them are appealed because if they're really that stale, those constructive discharge claims are usually thrown out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The case is litigated on other grounds.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Carroll.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, you just sort of made those two synonymous. But they don't have to be synonymous. A matter might mean the claim, not the particular discriminatory conduct that's the predicate for the claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I mean, this is an unusual kind of claim, and it's an unusual kind of claim because there are predicate acts and then there is also a resignation which clearly has to occur before the suit can be brought. And when there is this, you know, this composite set of things that has to go on before a suit, it seems to me that it's at least approaching the kind of possible ambiguous -- ambiguous stage to say, yeah, that's a matter, that's a practice that both of those things have to be part of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about that he hasn't got a claim? He can't even --  you can't come to court with a claim for constructive discharge until you've said I'm discharged. So he --  you're suggesting that the time runs from a time when he does not yet have a ripe claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But then are you saying that constructive discharge will --  will lead to a cause of action only when it is so close to the precipitating event that they are almost contemporaneous?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When, under your view, when is there a constructive discharge that itself leads to triggering the statute of limitations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: They're almost contemporaneous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, the matter complained of here is a constructive discharge. In a tort suit or many the matter complained of is negligent behavior leading to an injury. I take it in the tort suit the statute of limitations doesn't begin to run until there is harm.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. If that's generally true in a tort suit, and my guess is in a contract suit for breach of contract, if the contracting party sent the ships out and you knew that it wouldn't be delivered, it's not actionable until it isn't delivered and I guess there are ways around that, but my point is generally in the law where the matter complained of is a certain kind of incident in the world, negligence leading to harm, action of a discriminatory, et cetera, nature that leads to a discharge, normally the statute of limitations begins to run when the harm occurs. Now why should it be any different here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Of course, he could have, but we're talking about only the constructive discharge part. I mean, sometimes defendants do seven bad things at once, or at least allegedly bad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And we're only talking about one of them, the one that we're talking about is the constructive-discharge claim. So I go back to my question about negligence, because that was the first course I took in law school so I remember that, but the -- the fact is why should we treat this any differently?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because you have to, as you said, in the a tort case it's not just that the person behaved negligently, but that negligence had to result in a harm.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So I'm just -- that's the only simpleminded analogy I'm drawing and I wonder why it doesn't work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose there was evidence that the employer had a continuing intent to force Mr. Green's resignation. So you've got emails that say, Mr. Green is causing trouble for us by charging us with discrimination, we're going to do A, B, C, D and E to force him to retire. And then on the day when he quits there is another email that says, Hallelujah, we've achieved our objective, he's retired. Now when would it run in that situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Wouldn't it run from the date of discharge because there would be an intent at -- as of that date?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Let me clarify it. So nothing more is done. There are all these acts up to a certain point, and then days, days pass and the employee resigns, but the employer has all along had the intention of forcing the resignation. So on the date of the resignation the employer intends to cause a discharge for discriminatory reason.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's the -- now, I'm getting this more clearly because your response to my question, which is now relevant to this too, is, look, the plaintiff was hurt on the very day that last act was performed, indeed he suffered because he saw the act being performed, and that was one of the things that led him later to quit. So let's count that as the injury. And let's count the whole thing complete as of that time. That's basically the argument for your side, I think. And now the argument against you is that's going to be a nightmare. Because there will be in fact a whole range of acts, a whole series in many cases and will then, in order to run the statute of limitations, have to get into the question of which of those acts -- maybe there were some he didn't know about -- which of those acts actually did produce harm and which did not. And he just really won't know when to bring his lawsuit as compared with the comparatively simple thing: He quits.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, that's true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: There's something more than just simplicity, which is, you know, suppose you had a case where somebody is first demoted and then somebody is fired. You would never say, oh, he was demoted. He suffered the injury then, it just raised the stakes. You would say, no, there's two independent things and now he can bring a termination claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And the power of the constructive-discharge claim is to say the exact same thing really has happened here, that once you lose the job, it's more than the stakes have been raised. It's that there is a separate injury that then becomes legally actionable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But if we're going to say, yes, these are different and for some purposes we're going to look to the fiction and for other purposes we're not going to look to the fiction, it seems to me as though here it makes sense to take account of the fiction in the sense that the person cannot bring a claim until the resignation has happened. So that's the kind of paradigmatic case in which, boy, there is something really powerful pushing that, yes, you can -- you should recognize the constructive discharge as a discharge in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The language we're focusing on here is the language of a regulation. What statutory language does that regulation implement?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You say this isn't going to be a problem much. I think it's going to be a problem a lot of times. People are in jobs and they're, you know, suffering this particular type of adverse work environment or discrimination, but quitting your job is a very big deal. I think you have to plan out when Alderson Reporting Company that's going to be, and just because you can't take it anymore doesn't mean that you could quit work right away.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, sure, it doesn't require you to quit, it just requires you to tell your boss, you know, I can't take this anymore. And now I've got to conciliate with you, but, you know, it creates complications in the workforce if you raise that type of issue.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I suspect most employers could figure out who is complaining in these types of situations.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What --  what is your position on the government's stance?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Factual question.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I think it's an example of the difficulty of trying to figure out when the discrimination occurred if you have this last-act kind of thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you do with Suders that seemed to distinguish two things; one was the hostile environment, and the second was the constructive discharge. And the Court said that that -- that the hostile environment is a lesser included component of the more serious constructive-discharge claim.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Wolfman, four minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. That's true, and that's why I thought --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- that was an open question. But the government, Mr. Gannon says that in fact the district court said that you chose to retire on -- in December, and you didn't appeal that finding by the district court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is your response to her -- I think she's saying in most of these cases there is a hostile work environment. Where there is a hostile work environment you have days from the last act, and so what we should do is look at this injury as simply one more injury caused by a hostile work environment. And just as you don't look at the date of injury there, you look to the environment, et cetera, we so do the same thing here. It's simpler, et cetera.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Carroll, this Court appointed you to brief and argue this case as an amicus curiae in support of the judgment below. You have ably discharged that responsibility, for which the Court is grateful. The case is submitted.
